body: We'd love to know however much more you can tell us, of course.

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle I meant if there's any logging flags you want me to enable, let me know. The failing tests are integration tests of Dropbox's deployment system running inside docker containers.
`GRPC_TRACE=all GRPC_VERBOSITY=debug` are great environment variables. If that's too much see if changing `all` to `api` helps. Those are my strong go-tos; I'd have to look around for others.
(FYI, I have temporarily disabled 1.8.0 from PyPI, so make sure you are actually running 1.8.0 and not 1.7.3 if you are re-fetching from pip)

Yes, we are running 1.8, we have an internal mirror so we've already pulled it from PyPI and we version things explicitly.

OK, will give the logging a shot

```================================== failure ===================================

@nathanielmanistaatgoogle let me know if there's any other logs I can provide that will help you debug!
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle have you had a chance to look into this issue? :)
@nathanielmanistaatgoogle this issue happens when you have a process that has initialized grpc call `subprocess.Popen` with `close_fds=True` set, and is a regression from 1.7. does that help?

More data: siwtching from `subprocess` to `subprocess32` seems to "fix" this, and the failing tests were running in docker so that might be related (we have other code in non-docker using subprocess with close_fds but it might not have failed due to lacking test coverage)
Looks like the issues were mostly caused by fork, although we do seem to see a new segfault. Will open a separate issue once we have some coredumps
